I'm all in favor of the SAT's, for the reasons you mentioned and more. But other tests? How does one measure creativity? I doubt very much that an assessment of "divergent thinking" will identify a future Mozart. And, really, do we want all students to be creative? It is a trait I value highly, but it seems of limited use to a student who plans to be an accountant, unless, perhaps, he plans to work for the mob. Similarly, "personal intelligence" is well and good and useful in life, but I don't know that it's necessary for the research chemist who will have a closer relationship with test tubes than with human beings.

The danger here is that, in reducing all of these qualities to test scores, we will end up enforcing conventionality based on imperfect and only partly understood measures. In fact, the existing admissions process works pretty well to the extent that we let it as a means to match students with appropriate schools. In part, that's because it isn't based on a single, simple metric the way admissions are in most other countries. There are multiple ways for a student to shine -- grades, recommendations, interviews, test scores, accomplishments.

I don't know personally of many cases in which the process didn't result in a reasonable match between student and educational opportunity. I'm more concerned about economic barriers, and about pressures that lead schools to discard important measures like the SAT.

EU imports of Russian natural gas had been declining before the current turmoil, not increasing, this is a trend that is expected to continue. Fracking has dramatically increased sources of oil and natural gas outside of Russia. Facilities for the export of LNG from the US to Europe and other nations around the world will be completed in the near future. The traditional oil exporters of Russia and Saudi Arabia have been well aware that the increasing competition from these other sources of petroleum based energy will significantly affect their future revenues and political power on the international stage.

South Stream will not increase the overall percentage of Russian natural gas to Europe, it will simply allow Russia to bypass pipelines that pass through Ukraine.

The weapon of oil/natural gas shutoff will be harder for Russia to wield now than when it when it was a member of the Soviet Union because it is dependent on the revenue derived from its energy exports to the West in order to buy the manufactured goods from the West that it needs. It also needs the financial investments of Western companies to expand and extract its mineral wealth. Military intervention would undoubtably cause hardships directly and indirectly on Russian citizens.
